awd_titl_txt: Physics-Informed Structure-Preserving Numerical Approximations of Thermodynamically Consistent Models for Non-equilibrium Phenomena
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-equilibrium phenomena, including those described by non-isothermal and isothermal hydrodynamic models with applications to complex multiphase fluids, are ubiquitous in science. They require well-developed models to describe their dynamics but pose challenges to the algorithms for their approximations. This project aims to establish a computational framework for models of non-equilibrium phenomena that have the property of being thermodynamically consistent. The algorithms to be designed will preserve the desired properties at the discrete levels. Furthermore, these numerical schemes will be utilized to simulate and investigate the dynamics of several classes of non-equilibrium models in an accurate and efficient way. Software will be developed on high-performance computing platforms and made available to the public. Students will be involved and trained through research involvement in the project. 
  
Thermodynamically consistent (TC) partial differential equation (PDE) systems, derivable from the GENERIC formalism (General Equation for Non-Equilibrium Reversible-Irreversible Coupling), encompass a large class of models in science and engineering for non-equilibrium phenomena. The project will (1) establish a paradigm for designing structure-preserving, high order, energy stable, and efficient numerical approximations to solve TCPDE systems by exploiting the mathematical structure of the TC models and reformulating them using the GENERIC formalism; (2) design physics-informed deep neural network frameworks to solve TCPDE models while preserving their structures and properties; (3) apply the numerical framework to investigate several classes of TC models; and (4) develop an object-oriented, open-source, and high-performance software package for hybrid GPU-CPU architectures. The outcomes will advance modeling, analysis, and numerical simulations of non-equilibrium thermodynamic and hydrodynamic models, fostering a deeper understanding of non-equilibrium phenomena in a wide range of applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PDE models describing non-equilibrium phenomena are typically derived from thermodynamic principles, such as entropy production and free energy dissipation, along with additional physical constraints (e.g., the maximum principle, volume conservation, and incompressibility). The primary objective of this project is to develop numerical methods for solving thermodynamically consistent PDEs (TCPDEs) while preserving their underlying structures and constraints.

The project has led to several significant advancements in numerical methods and theoretical frameworks for TCPDEs. First, it has resulted in the novel development of the auxiliary relaxation method for TCPDE model formulation with constraints and relaxation-based energy quadratization and scalar auxiliary variable techniques for energy-stable, structure-preserving algorithm developments. These modeling and numerical techniques ensure accurate simulations of multiphase and multicomponent complex systems. Second, a general model order reduction framework was developed to construct structure-preserving reduced-order models. This framework enables efficient computation of TCPDEs while maintaining their thermodynamical structures even in the reduced dimensions. Third, another key outcome is the development of a computational framework for thermodynamically consistent fluid-structure interactions that is applicable to complex and irregular physical geometries. Furthermore, another outcome is the integration of thermodynamic constraints with physics-informed neural networks to solve TCPDEs.

Motivated and guided by the intrinsic physical laws of the TCPDEs, the modeling and computational frameworks established in this project provide a robust platform for designing structure-preserving numerical algorithms with improved efficiency, stability, and accuracy for solving TCPDEs. The outcomes of this research have advanced the understanding of TCPDE systems and provided new computational and theoretical insights into modeling and simulating non-equilibrium phenomena.

Throughout the project, two M.S. students, three Ph.D. students, and five undergraduate students from Utah State University and Binghamton University participated in research projects focused on developing new computational methods for TCPDEs. These students gained valuable training and hands-on experience in advanced numerical techniques and computational mathematics. The project team has been highly productive with several high-quality publications that have already been widely cited in the research community. The project team has delivered over twenty presentations at various conferences and workshops, and effectively disseminated findings to the broader scientific community. The PI has incorporated some of these results into computational mathematics curricula at his home institutions. Furthermore, several algorithms and computational tools developed in this project have been made publicly available to better serve the research community.
